title: B-BOVID shows the way in Ecotourism
text:
23:00 CET B-BOVID shows the way in Ecotourism By GNA 
Mpohor, Oct 20, GNA - Mr. Issa Ouedraogo, the founder and chief executive Officer of B-BOVID, has asked farmers to inter plant their crops with trees in an effort to combat Climate Change. 
He said the effects of Climate Change on livelihoods was dire, explaining that it could cause food insecurity and poverty, therefore, it was necessary for the rural farmer to be empowered to use climate smart agriculture responses. 
Mr Ouedraogo was speaking with journalists during a facility visit to his 400-acre farmland comprising an agro-forestry, a diversified livelihood centre; and eco-tourism sites at Pretsea Nkwanta and Angu in the Western Region. 
He said the company was sensitising indigenous farmers through simple technology, demonstration farms, and other training programmes to encourage organic agriculture and aquaculture. 
The B-BOVID Company also offers corporate bodies, research and social institutions including orphanages, and the physically challenged an exciting facility excursion. 
The facility has space for horse and donkey riding, fishing, different species of animals, and many more recreational activities to learn about nature. 
Mr Ouedraogo said they had ICT training centre for farmers, organic vegetable demonstration farms, cassava, eco-garden, rubber nursery, oil palm plantation, palm oil, and kernel processing mills and organic restaurant. 
Mr. Yusif Habib, an Agro-forestry and Officer in-charge of Climate Change, with Transforming Rural Agricultural Communities through Organic Re-Engineering (TRACTOR), an NGO, encouraged farmers to blend food crops with tree species such as Prekese, Moringa, Hwenetia as they have medicinal properties. 
He said at present, TRACTOR was implementing some Agro-forestry projects in partnership with Coastal Sustainable Landscape Project (CSLP), US-Forest Service International Programme through USAID Ghana, to improve Ghana's forest cover and fight climate change. 
Mr. Habib said organic bee keeping could also become another avenue for wealth creation for farmers. 
GNA
